body:
@ijuma small doc change related zk sasl configs. "zookeeper.sasl.client" config is to enable sasl support on zk client. "zookeeper.sasl.clientconfig" config to specify the context key in the JAAS login file.

https://zookeeper.apache.org/doc/trunk/zookeeperProgrammers.html#sc_ZooKeeperAccessControl
@ijuma minor doc change

@guozhangwang i don't see how this change would have caused that failure.

> 1. Check if the result assignment is balanced.

The assignment is not always balanced, so i'm not sure this is going to be very effective.

>2. There are no new tasks created: sum of prevAssignedTasks should be equal to the new list of tasks.

It is already checked that no new tasks are created. line 79: `if (previouslyAssignedTaskIds.equals(taskIds) ...`

>3. no "new" client is likely joining (we cannot tell for sure): clientsWithoutPreviousActiveTasks should have some tasks in prevAssignedTasks meaning that it is not likely new clients;

Yes we can add a check for this

>4. no "old" client was likely to be dropped (again we cannot tell for sure so just heuristics): sum of clientsWithoutPreviousActiveTasks's prevAssignedTasks should cover noPreviousActiveAssignment, otherwise it is likely that some client has been dropped from the group.

I'll add some tests and checks for this

Also, it would be good to merge trunk into this branch. I know this can be annoying, but the request/response code has changed enough that some parts of the review can't be done properly without that.

@hachikuji I had initially thought of handling only unavailable partitions, but the PR currently does handle non-existent topics/partitions as well. This is similar to the behaviour in the producer when attempting to send a message to a partition when metadata is unavailable either because the topic doesn't exist or the leader is not known. The reason I was thinking of excluding `UnknownTopicOrPartitionException` initially was because this can be a result of a non-existent topic or an unauthorized topic. I didn't exclude this in the PR because this exception during fetch in the consumer and for send in the producer retry metadata refresh, so thought it was better to keep the code consistent. What do you think?

Yes, I will move the PR to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4631. I think it means closing and creating a new one for that. Will do that now. Thank you...
Moving this PR to KAFKA-4631.
This is the (second) PR from https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4779. See https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2608 for details.

@guozhangwang i've re-worked it a bit. I removed the optimisation as such as i found a more general solution.
Now, first, we try and assign the previousActiveTasks to the clients that previously had the active.
If there are still unassigned tasks, then try and assign to clients that had them as standby tasks (or have previously seen them)
Finally assign any remaining tasks across all clients.

@ijuma Thank you for the review. In most cases, old client will be waiting for server token inside the SASL authenticator and will treat the error code as a SASL challenge and fail to authenticate. It is also possible that a (eg. non-Java) client finishes authentication without waiting for data from server and treats the error code as a Kafka response and fails to parse the response. Either way, since the server disconnects straight after sending the error code, the client will process the disconnection and continue to re-create connections as today (treating authentication failures as connection failures).

FYI: System tests run here: http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2017-03-01--001.1488358155--confluentinc--exactly-once-message-format--c2a14f8/report.html. The one failure looks like a known problem, but I haven't investigated.

@guozhangwang with respect to multiple threads on the same JVM. There is only 1 Client per JVM, i.e., if there were 4 threads then the capacity of the Client would be 4. 

w.r.t. point 2. Yes i agree. I think we could add a further optimization where by we send the checkpointed offsets for each of these and try and use the client with the most recent offset.

For comparison, here is what it looks like with a `ConcurrentLinkedQueue`: https://github.com/hachikuji/kafka/commit/97c3284eeb14ca30abe68042bd81022206d70a80. It's actually fewer lines of code. The tradeoff is that per-node operations require iterating through the unsent request list, but in practice, I expect this is not a real issue.

@ijuma Thanks for reviewing the patch. This KIP depends on the KAFKA-4820 and I will rebase the patch after KAFKA-4820 is committed. And I will also explain the PurgeDataCommand in the mailing thread and the KIP wiki.

Initially we considered to use purge, truncate or delete in the method name. I don't have a strong preference among them. I chose purge because Joel/Becket prefers it and no one else raises concerns with it in the open source discussion. I think one reason is to distinguish it from `deleteTopic` method. Now that we have `data` in the name, I agree that it may be better to use `deleteDataBefore`. Let me propose it in the open source mailing list.

I think the purpose of including `data` in the method name is to distinguish it from `deleteTopic` method name. The reason of not having `data` in the API name PurgeRequest is because `ProduceRequest` or `FetchRequest` doesn't include `data` in the name.

The reason of including `before` in the method name is because we may want to have a method to delete data after a given offset in the future.

JDK 8 and Scala 2.12 test is failing which looks like an infrastructure and is unrelated.

@hachikuji Thanks for providing an example. In addition to the increased time-complexity for per-node operation, I think your patch is less efficient in the sense that `pendingRequestCount()`, `failUnsentRequests()` still requires global lock which means the user thread may block on these methods while another thread is blocked waiting on the `nioSelector.select(ms)`. In addition, your patch assumes that private methods such as `trySend()` must be called while holding the global lock, because otherwise one request may be sent multiple times when multiple threads call `trySend()`. This assumption is correct as of now, but is kind of error prone if some developer doesn't know about this and simply calls `trySend` without having the global lock.

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.10/1931/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.10).

> In addition to the increased time-complexity for per-node operation, I think your patch is less efficient in the sense that pendingRequestCount(), failUnsentRequests() still requires global lock which means the user thread may block on these methods while another thread is blocked waiting on the nioSelector.select(ms).

The method `pendingRequestCount()` must acquire the "global" lock protecting `NetworkClient` anyway, right? And `failUnsentRequests` does not actually need the lock since the unsent collection is safe to iterate concurrently.

> In addition, your patch assumes that private methods such as trySend() must be called while holding the global lock, because otherwise one request may be sent multiple times when multiple threads call trySend(). This assumption is correct as of now, but is kind of error prone if some developer doesn't know about this and simply calls trySend without having the global lock.

This makes no sense to me. If you are concerned about the assumption, either make the synchronization explicit by acquiring the necessary lock within `trySend` or just add some documentation. In your patch, we also have to make assumptions about locking order which a developer might not be aware of, right? Either way, we depend on reviewers to make sure developers don't do dumb things.

The benefit of the approach is that it is easier to understand. For concurrent code, that is a rather big win. If you really insist on adding a second lock, then I'd recommend following the pattern suggested by Ismael above. However, at the moment, I don't see a compelling reason to increase complexity.

@hachikuji I agree that `pendingRequestCount()` needs global lock anyway so it is not an issue. I also agree that the assumption is not an issue.

Regarding `failUnsentRequests`, if two threads call `failUnsentRequests` concurrently and `failUnsentRequests` does not require the global lock, is it possible that call back of a given request is executed multiple times? I am thinking of the scenario that both threads reach the same request, execute callback, and then remove it from iterator. If this is not an issue then I am happy to do what you suggested :)

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed):

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.11/1935/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.11).

> Regarding failUnsentRequests, if two threads call failUnsentRequests concurrently and failUnsentRequests does not require the global lock, is it possible that call back of a given request is executed multiple times? I am thinking of the scenario that both threads reach the same request, execute callback, and then remove it from iterator. If this is not an issue then I am happy to do what you suggested :)

To tell you the truth, I'd prefer to keep `failUnsentRequests()` under the lock to ensure that callbacks cannot be invoked concurrently. There's enough trickiness here already without having to think about the thread safety of callbacks and nondeterministic orders of invocations. If we want `failUnsentRequests()` to be non-blocking, maybe we could add the associated `Node` to a local collection and then do the actual work within `poll()`. Then we could use `wakeup()` to interrupt another thread in the middle of poll(). Would that work?

@hachikuji I think your solution would work. Strictly speaking my patch is better in the sense that 1) the per-node operation is faster and 2) `failUnsentRequests(..)` can be executed while `client.poll()` holds the lock and still make sure that callback will not be invoked concurrently (because they are protected by `synchronize(unsent)`). But I am fine with this since the performance impact should be small. Both Becket and I think the code may be a bit simpler using `synchronized(unsent)` than using `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` but such opinion is subjective and there is no need to argue over this.

Thus I am happy to take your suggestion of using `ConcurrentLinkedQueue` so that we can get it fixed fast.
